content.raw: since the `link[234]_frame`s have joints as their parent frame, I assume the link they are rigidly affixed to is based on the joint's implicit frame affixed link, which is defined below. perhaps we could move that definition before this example so we can state that "`link2_frame` is rigidly affixed to `link2` as the child link of `joint1`, etc."
content.html: since the link[234]_frames have joints as their parent frame, I assume the link they are rigidly affixed to is based on the joint's implicit frame affixed link, which is defined below. perhaps we could move that definition before this example so we can state that "link2_frame is rigidly affixed to link2 as the child link of joint1, etc."

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
As you [discussed in PR 7](#!/osrf/sdf_tutorials/pull-requests/7/pose-frame-semantics-proposal-for-new/activity#comment-99893484), adding a `Jc` frame to the child link requires redundant information due to our name scoping rules, but adding an implicit frame for each joint added to both the parent and child link would be a simple way to get around that. I was about to say that it would impose additional naming restrictions on `//link/*` elements to avoid name collisions with joints like `<collision name="joint1">` and `<visual name="joint1">`, however unlikely. But I remembered that our proposal calls for `//pose@frame` to only accept names of model, link, joint, and frame tags, so I guess the only added restriction would be that you couldn't have a `//link/frame@name` that collides with a joint name `<link><frame name="joint1">`.

What do you think?
content.html:
As you discussed in PR 7, adding a Jc frame to the child link requires redundant information due to our name scoping rules, but adding an implicit frame for each joint added to both the parent and child link would be a simple way to get around that. I was about to say that it would impose additional naming restrictions on //link/* elements to avoid name collisions with joints like <collision name="joint1"> and <visual name="joint1">, however unlikely. But I remembered that our proposal calls for //pose@frame to only accept names of model, link, joint, and frame tags, so I guess the only added restriction would be that you couldn't have a //link/frame@name that collides with a joint name <link><frame name="joint1">.

What do you think?

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
One thing we haven't talked about yet is circular references and validity of kinematic graphs. I just thought of it because with this you would also have to be careful of the invalid circular statement in the following snippet:

~~~
<link name="parent"/>
<joint name="joint1">
  <pose frame="parent">
  <parent>parent</parent>
  <child>child</child>
</joint>
<link name="child">
  <pose frame="child/joint1">{X_JcC}</pose> <!-- INVALID: circular reference -->
  <pose frame="parent/joint1">{X_JcC}</pose> <!-- VALID -->
  <pose frame="joint1">{X_JcC}</pose> <!-- VALID -->
</link>
~~~
content.html:
One thing we haven't talked about yet is circular references and validity of kinematic graphs. I just thought of it because with this you would also have to be careful of the invalid circular statement in the following snippet:

<link name="parent"/>
<joint name="joint1">
  <pose frame="parent">
  <parent>parent</parent>
  <child>child</child>
</joint>
<link name="child">
  <pose frame="child/joint1">{X_JcC}</pose> <!-- INVALID: circular reference -->
  <pose frame="parent/joint1">{X_JcC}</pose> <!-- VALID -->
  <pose frame="joint1">{X_JcC}</pose> <!-- VALID -->
</link>

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
My concern with having an implicit frame is that when said frame is used in `//link/frame/pose[@frame]` it can give the impression that the scoping rules are being violated.

```
<link name="L1">
   <frame name="F1">
       <pose frame="J1">...</pose> <!-- Accessing "J1"  here appears to be a violation of the scoping rules -->
   </frame>
</link>
<joint name="J1"/>
```
content.html:
My concern with having an implicit frame is that when said frame is used in //link/frame/pose[@frame] it can give the impression that the scoping rules are being violated.

<link name="L1">
   <frame name="F1">
       <pose frame="J1">...</pose> <!-- Accessing "J1"  here appears to be a violation of the scoping rules -->
   </frame>
</link>
<joint name="J1"/>

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
I'm rewriting your example slightly to clarify that `L1` is connected by `J1`

~~~
<link name="P"/>
<joint name="J1" type="fixed">
  <parent>P</parent>
  <child>L1</child>
</joint>
<link name="L1">
  <frame name="F1">
    <pose frame="J1">...</pose> <!-- Accessing "J1"  here appears to be a violation of the scoping rules -->
  </frame>
</link>
~~~
content.html:
I'm rewriting your example slightly to clarify that L1 is connected by J1

<link name="P"/>
<joint name="J1" type="fixed">
  <parent>P</parent>
  <child>L1</child>
</joint>
<link name="L1">
  <frame name="F1">
    <pose frame="J1">...</pose> <!-- Accessing "J1"  here appears to be a violation of the scoping rules -->
  </frame>
</link>

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
From re-reading these a few times, I’m thinking that this is more heavily coupled to name nesting.

I’m going to remove the secondary suggestion using nesting \(\`parent/j1\`\), and make a note that this referencing will be subject to the Nesting proposal.
content.html:
From re-reading these a few times, I’m thinking that this is more heavily coupled to name nesting.

I’m going to remove the secondary suggestion using nesting (`parent/j1`), and make a note that this referencing will be subject to the Nesting proposal.

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
I'm not sure if we need explicit joint frames, but the most relevant use case I can think of is `<joint><sensor type="forcetorque">`, which has already added some custom elements to try to deal with frames:

* http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=sensor#sensor_force_torque
* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/sdf6/sdf/1.6/forcetorque.sdf
content.html:
I'm not sure if we need explicit joint frames, but the most relevant use case I can think of is <joint><sensor type="forcetorque">, which has already added some custom elements to try to deal with frames:

  • http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=sensor#sensor_force_torque
  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/sdf6/sdf/1.6/forcetorque.sdf

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw: This doesn't make sense to me either. There is a valid question here: to which link is the model frame affixed? But I'm not sure "parent link determined by joint connections" makes sense; what if you have a model with a single link and no joints? I feel like this is where the canonical link concept is used in gazebo. Is that what you want to formalize here?
content.html: This doesn't make sense to me either. There is a valid question here: to which link is the model frame affixed? But I'm not sure "parent link determined by joint connections" makes sense; what if you have a model with a single link and no joints? I feel like this is where the canonical link concept is used in gazebo. Is that what you want to formalize here?

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
I think it would be useful if the meaning of `pose[@frame]` is consistent across the board. Right now, it means "affixed_to" in `//model/frame/pose[@frame]` but means "expressed w.r.t" (and NOT affixed to) in `//link/frame[@frame]`, `/model/pose[@frame]`, `//link/pose[@frame]`, and `//include/pose[@frame]`. My suggestion would be to removed the "affixed_to" semantics from the pose tag and put it in the frame tag with an extra attribute. For example we can do:

```xml
<model name="M">
  <frame name="F1" affixed_to="L1">
     <pose frame="L1">{X_L1F1}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L1 and pose expressed w.r.t L1 -->
  </frame>
  <frame name="F2" affixed_to="L2">
     <pose>{X_MF2}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L2 but pose expressed w.r.t M -->
  </frame>
  
  <link name="L1"/>
   <link name="L2"/>
</model>
```

I realize there is an exception with `//link/frame` in that it can't have an `affixed_to` attribute, but, in my mind, that's easier to reason about and remember.
content.html:
I think it would be useful if the meaning of pose[@frame] is consistent across the board. Right now, it means "affixed_to" in //model/frame/pose[@frame] but means "expressed w.r.t" (and NOT affixed to) in //link/frame[@frame], /model/pose[@frame], //link/pose[@frame], and //include/pose[@frame]. My suggestion would be to removed the "affixed_to" semantics from the pose tag and put it in the frame tag with an extra attribute. For example we can do:

<model name="M">
  <frame name="F1" affixed_to="L1">
     <pose frame="L1">{X_L1F1}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L1 and pose expressed w.r.t L1 -->
  </frame>
  <frame name="F2" affixed_to="L2">
     <pose>{X_MF2}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L2 but pose expressed w.r.t M -->
  </frame>

  <link name="L1"/>
   <link name="L2"/>
</model>

I realize there is an exception with //link/frame in that it can't have an affixed_to attribute, but, in my mind, that's easier to reason about and remember.

     <pose>{X_MF2}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L2 but pose expressed w.r.t L2 -->
~~~

should it say: `but pose expressed w.r.t M` (ie `L2` -> `M`)
content.html:
@azeey in the following line of your example:

     <pose>{X_MF2}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L2 but pose expressed w.r.t L2 -->

should it say: but pose expressed w.r.t M (ie L2 -> M)

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
Revelation per f2f:

* Every `//model/frame` needs `@affixed_to`, and `frame/pose[@frame]` should resolve by default to this frame.
* If we permit `//link/frame`, it complicates scoping rules \(per below discussion\), because they’re not as powerful \(limited semantics\). It also adds edges to `//link/frame[@affixed_to]`.

So maybe just permit only `//model/frame` and \(maybe\) `//world/frame`
content.html:
Revelation per f2f:

  • Every //model/frame needs @affixed_to, and frame/pose[@frame] should resolve by default to this frame.
  • If we permit //link/frame, it complicates scoping rules (per below discussion), because they’re not as powerful (limited semantics). It also adds edges to //link/frame[@affixed_to].

So maybe just permit only //model/frame and (maybe) //world/frame

content.html:

I do like this more. I think it’s still a wee bit confusing when seeing that //pose/frame is really “expressed-in” rather than “affixed-to and expressed-in”, but this does simplify the specification of what’s affixed.

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw: If it's useful, then a relevant example would help communicate that. I assume this means a model that has `<frame>` tags but no `<link>`s? My first guess is that a model with no links is just attached to the world. We use `<joint>` to express parent/child relationships between links; if we aren't using the `affixed_to` attribute for frames, maybe we would need something other way to affix a frame to a link?
content.html: If it's useful, then a relevant example would help communicate that. I assume this means a model that has <frame> tags but no <link>s? My first guess is that a model with no links is just attached to the world. We use <joint> to express parent/child relationships between links; if we aren't using the affixed_to attribute for frames, maybe we would need something other way to affix a frame to a link?
